title: Advanced Passive & Causative Structures
description: Master advanced passive constructions and causative structures for discussing scientific processes and having things done.

rules.title: Passive with Modal Verbs
rules.explanation: Combine modal verbs with passive voice to express possibility, necessity, or ability in passive form. The structure is: modal + be + past participle.

examples.sentence: The experiment must be conducted under controlled conditions.
New treatments could be developed within the next decade.
examples.translation: 새로운 치료법이 향후 10년 내에 개발될 수 있다.

examples.sentence: The data should be analyzed before drawing conclusions.
examples.translation: 결론을 내리기 전에 데이터가 분석되어야 한다.

rules.title: Perfect Passive
rules.explanation: Use perfect passive to emphasize that an action has been completed. The structure varies by tense: has/have been + past participle (present perfect), had been + past participle (past perfect).
rules.structure: has/have been + past participle (present perfect) | had been + past participle (past perfect)

examples.sentence: The vaccine has been tested on thousands of volunteers.
The research had been funded by the government for years.
examples.translation: 그 연구는 수년간 정부의 지원을 받아왔다.

examples.sentence: Many discoveries have been made using this methodology.
examples.translation: 이 방법론을 사용하여 많은 발견이 이루어졌다.

rules.title: Passive Infinitive and Gerund
rules.explanation: Use passive infinitive (to be + past participle) after certain verbs and adjectives. Use passive gerund (being + past participle) after prepositions and certain verbs.
rules.structure: to be + past participle | being + past participle

examples.sentence: The prototype needs to be tested before production.
Scientists expect the results to be published next month.
examples.translation: 과학자들은 결과가 다음 달에 발표될 것으로 예상한다.

examples.sentence: Nobody likes being criticized for their work.
examples.translation: 아무도 자신의 연구에 대해 비판받는 것을 좋아하지 않는다.

rules.title: Causative: Have/Get Something Done
rules.explanation: Use causative structures when someone else does something for you or on your behalf. 'Have something done' is more formal; 'get something done' is more informal.

examples.sentence: The company had the software developed by external contractors.
examples.translation: 그 회사는 외부 계약자들에게 소프트웨어를 개발하게 했다.

examples.sentence: We got the samples analyzed at an independent laboratory.
examples.translation: 우리는 독립 연구소에서 샘플을 분석하게 했다.

examples.sentence: The university is having a new research facility built.
examples.translation: 대학교는 새로운 연구 시설을 짓게 하고 있다.

rules.title: Causative: Make/Have/Let/Get Someone Do
rules.explanation: Use these causative verbs to describe causing someone to perform an action. 'Make' implies force, 'have' is neutral, 'let' implies permission, and 'get' requires 'to' before the infinitive.
rules.structure: make/have/let + object + bare infinitive | get + object + to infinitive

examples.sentence: The professor made the students repeat the experiment.
The team leader had the researchers verify the data.
The ethics committee let the trial proceed.
We got the experts to review our methodology.

rules.title: Impersonal Passive with 'It'
rules.explanation: Use impersonal passive constructions with 'it' to report beliefs, claims, or knowledge without specifying who holds them. Common with verbs like believe, say, think, know, report.
rules.structure: It + is/was + past participle + that clause

examples.sentence: It is believed that the universe is expanding.
It has been reported that a new species was discovered.
It is thought that this treatment could be effective.
examples.translation: 이 치료법이 효과적일 수 있다고 생각된다.

exercises.question: The research _____ by a team of international scientists.
The samples need _____ (analyze) before the deadline.
We had the prototype _____ by external engineers.
The professor made the students _____ (redo) the experiment.
It _____ that climate change will have severe consequences.
The vaccine _____ (test) on thousands of participants so far.

exercises.original: The company hired someone to develop the software.
exercises.answer: The company had the software developed.

exercises.question: She got her colleagues _____ (review) the paper.
The new drug _____ approved by regulators yet.
